data.name: heading
data.body: Ac voltage applied to an inductor

data.name: image
data.body: /assets/alternating-current/image7.png

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Above figure shows an AC source connected to an inductor. Usually, inductors have appreciable resistance in their windings, but we shall assume that this inductor has negligible resistance. Thus, the circuit is a purely inductive AC circuit. Let the voltage across the source be \( v = V_m \sin(\omega t) \). Using Kirchhoff’s loop rule:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \sum {\varepsilon (t)} = 0 \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Since there is no resistor in the circuit:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[  V - L\frac{di}{dt} = 0  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where the second term is the self-induced Faraday emf in the inductor, and \( L \) is the self-inductance of the inductor. The negative sign follows from Lenz’s law.Replacing \( V \) by \( v_m \sin(\omega t) \), we get:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[\frac{di}{dt} = \frac{v}{L} = \frac{v_m}{L} \sin(\omega t)\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The above equation implies that the equation for \( i(t) \), the current as a function of time, must be such that its slope \( \frac{di}{dt} \) is a sinusoidally varying quantity, with the same phase as the source voltage and an amplitude given by \( \frac{v_m}{L} \). To obtain the current, we integrate \( \frac{di}{dt} \) with respect to time:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[\int \frac{di}{dt} dt = \int \sin(\omega t) \, d\left(\frac{v}{L}\right) dt\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This represents the integration of the rate of change of current with respect to time (\( \frac{di}{dt} \)) with respect to time, which equals the integration of \( \sin(\omega t) \) with respect to \( \frac{v}{L} \) with respect to \( t \).

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ i = -\frac{v_m}{\omega L} \cos(\omega t) + \text{constant} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The integration constant has the dimension of current and is time independent. Since the source has an electromotive force (emf) which oscillates symmetrically about zero, the current it sustains also oscillates symmetrically about zero, so that no constant or time-independent component of the current exists. Therefore, the integration constant is zero.

data.name: expression
data.body: \[  -\cos(\omega t) = {\sin(\omega t - \frac{\pi}{2}) } \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Now,

data.name: paragraph
data.body: \[  i = i_m{\sin(\omega t - \frac{\pi}{2}) } \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Where \( i_m = \frac{v_m}{\omega L} \) is the amplitude of the current. The quantity \( \omega L \) is analogous to the resistance and is called inductive reactance, denoted by \( X_L \): \( X_L = \omega L \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The amplitude of the current is, then \( i_m = \frac{v_m}{X_L} \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The dimension of inductive reactance is the same as that of resistance, and its SI unit is ohm (\( \Omega \)). The inductive reactance limits the current in a purely inductive circuit in the same way as the resistance limits the current in a purely resistive circuit. The inductive reactance is directly proportional to the inductance and to the frequency of the current.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Comparing the source voltage and the current in an inductor shows that the current lags the voltage by \( \frac{\pi}{2} \) or one-quarter (\( \frac{1}{4} \)) cycle.

data.name: image
data.body: /assets/alternating-current/image5.png

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Above figure shows the voltage and the current phasors in the present case at instant \( t_1 \). The current phasor \( I \) is \( \frac{\pi}{2} \) (or 90 degrees) behind the voltage phasor \( V \).

data.name: image
data.body: /assets/alternating-current/image8.png

data.name: paragraph
data.body: From the above figure, we see that the current reaches its maximum value later than the voltage by one-fourth of a period \( \frac{\pi}{2\omega} \). You have seen that an inductor has reactance that limits current similar to resistance in a DC circuit. Does it also consume power like a resistance? Let us try to find out.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The instantaneous power supplied to the inductor is:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[P = iv = i_m \sin(\omega t - \frac{\pi}{2}) v_m\sin (\omega t) = -i_m v_m   \sin(\omega t) \cos(\omega t) = - \frac{i_m v_m}{2} \sin( 2 \omega t)\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: So, the average power over a complete cycle is

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ P(t) = \omega L \sin^2(2\omega t) = -\frac{v_m i_m}{\omega} \sin(2\omega t) = 0 \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Since the average of \( \sin(2 \omega t) \) over a complete cycle is zero. Thus, the average power supplied to an inductor over one complete cycle is zero
